title: Energy conservation - U of electron-field system

content.question: An electron is initially at rest in a uniform electric field <math alttext="vector E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover accent="true"><mi>E</mi><mo>â†’</mo></mover></math> that points upward, as shown in the figure. After the electron starts moving in the field, what happens to the electric potential energy <math alttext="U sub e f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>e-f</mtext></msub></math> of the electron-field system? What evidence or reasoning best supports the claim? Gravitational forces can be considered to be negligible.

choices.label: <math alttext="U sub e f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>e-f</mtext></msub></math> increases. The electron moves in the opposite direction that a positive charge would move.

<math alttext="U sub e f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>e-f</mtext></msub></math> increases. The electron is accelerated by the field and has an increasing kinetic energy.
<math alttext="U sub e f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>e-f</mtext></msub></math> decreases. The electron moves upward.

<math alttext="U sub e f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>e-f</mtext></msub></math> decreases. The speed of the electron increases due to the field and the electron has an increasing kinetic energy.

content.answer: <math alttext="U sub e f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>e-f</mtext></msub></math> decreases. The speed of the electron increases due to the field and the electron has an increasing kinetic energy.
